abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Federal Highway
            Maintenance Project for Mexico were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: contracting and road management innovations can
            improve maintenance budgeting practices as well. The two
            innovations introduced by the project, the Pilot Project for
            Comprehensive Maintenance by Contract (PPMC) and the Highway
            Design and Maintenance Model (HDM-4), contributed to improve
            Direccibn General de Concesibn de Carreteras (DGCC's)
            maintenance budgeting. First, the PPMC, a three year
            comprehensive maintenance program required three years for
            implementation and therefore, its contracting made necessary
            the approval of a multiyear budget until then not used by
            the DGCC in its contracts. The introduction of multiyear
            contracts will allow in Secretariat of Communications and
            Transport (SCT) to tender bigger works in the future, which
            until now have been split in different contracts to allow
            for execution in one year and a half for budgetary reasons
            (there is a six month grace period to end the works
            contracted out in the previous fiscal year. Second, the
            HDM-4 requires improved and expanded inventories and basic
            data on road condition and allows for in-depth analyses of
            current asset capacity and condition, service demand over a
            considerable horizon, detailed assessments, and multi-year
            maintenance plans. Funding for road maintenance becomes more
            stable when the planning process improves and enough
            resources are allocated to projects. The project routine
            maintenance share was originally 30 percent periodic
            maintenance was 50 percent, reconstruction was 9 percent,
            and highways signposts represented 10.5 percent. A SCT
            recommendation at the end of the program was that the share
            of routine maintenance in future similar contracts should be
            higher, not less than 50 percent. In this respect, it is
            worth to mention that the PPCM, as designed, had a routine
            and periodic maintenance share of about 80 percent.

abstracts.cdata!:
The overarching development objective of
            the Federal highway Maintenance Project is primarily to
            improve transport efficiency on the federal road network.
            Complementary objectives include improving the
            rehabilitation and maintenance planning performance of the
            Secretariat for Finance and Public Credit (SCT); and
            enhancing private sector participation in road maintenance.
            There are four project components. The first supports the
            SCT's 2001-2003 programs for highway maintenance and
            bridge rehabilitation along key segments of the federal
            highway network. The second component introduces
            comprehensive maintenance by contract through a pilot
            program, including technical assistance for design and
            implementation. This three-year program includes
            comprehensive maintenance, repair of selected segments of
            roads and bridges, some minor works preparation of
            short-term implementation programs, and training and
            management of the program. The third component constructs
            vehicle weight control stations. The fourth component
            supports the implementation of the Highway Development and
            Management Model in the General Directorate for Maintenance
            of Roads (DGCC) and its departmental offices; develops a
            strategy for road decentralization; implements a road
            financing mechanism; implements a strategy for toll roads;
            and trains staff in the SCT directorates most involved in
            the project, emphasizing technical, managerial, and
            administrative training.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Second Highway Rehabilitation
            Project : social assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This social assessment (SA) examines the
            possibility of negative impacts as a result of the Second
            Highways Rehabilitation Project, particularly regarding
            potential involuntary resettlement by indigenous
            populations, since marginal groups were identified, namely
            few indigenous populations, migrant rural workers, and small
            suburban communities, who could suffer adverse social
            impacts. However, the report stipulates that the right of
            way will not be affected, i.e., resettlement issues
            resulting from land acquisition will not occur, since
            basically, the federal road network encompasses already
            developed urban areas. Furthermore, the Ministry of
            Communications and Transport should provide progress reports
            on the implementation of each subproject in compliance with
            the right of way, and, relevant information on the traffic
            generated should be made available, to estimate beneficial,
            or negative impacts on local populations, a measure which
            should be incorporated in all roads and highway projects. In
            addition, the SA indicates that highway projects mostly
            generate beneficial social aspects, since they improve the
            economy, as commercial activity increases; promote cultural
            activities, as regional, national, and international tourism
            increases; and, improve social aspects, as increased access
            to education, health, and social benefits facilitate the
            well-being of distant populations.
